comments:
I have the nasty effect, that after refactoring a class (either by selecting in 
the Package Explorer or selecting the class' name in the Editor and - in both 
cases - right-clicking => Refactor => Rename and entering a new name) 
afterwards the editor blocks any further editing of that class (i.e. one can 
type or try to move the cursor using the keyboard) but the editor won't react 
any more. The only thing left is to close that view and re-open that file in 
the editor.

If one tries to rename the file twice while the editor window to that class 
remains open (this is only possible in the PackageExplorer since after the 
refactoring the Editor won't allow you to select the classname nor react onto 
the right-click) I get the following Exception:

----------------------------
An exception has been caught while processing the refactoring 'Rename
'foo.java' to 'bar.java''.

Reason:
Assertion failed:

Click "Undo" to undo all successfully executed changes.
Click "Abort" to abort the refactoring.
[Undo] [Abort]
----------------------------

This is on 3.0M8 on Windows XP using J2SDK 1.4.2

Michael

PS.: the corresponding entry in the .log reads:

Move to Platform/Text
Do you have a reproducible test case?
Created an attachment (id=10163)
contains the mentioned test-case
That one was easy ;-):

I created a new Java project "test", in it a new package "myPackage" and in
that two new classes "A" and "B" (I don't even know, whether the package
and the two classes would be necessary...).
I double-click one of the classes, say "B" so that the editor opens. Then I
select that class in the Package-Explorer, right-click => Refactor =>
Rename and entered e.g. "C" (to rename "B" to "C"). After hitting enter and
clicking into the edit-window of the just renamed class the editor is dead
(below I append the corresponding stack trace from the .log file).

(See attached file: test.zip)

Hope that helps,
Michael

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

PS.: it would really make live easier if one could simply reply to Bugzilla's 
emails. Currently, if one naively does, the mail bounces back after a while 
telling one about an 'unknown user: "bugzilla-daemon"'...

But I guess for that I would have to submit yet another bugreport...
works for me using I200405131600 or newer.
